elements.content: Hydrothermal in situ [2 + 3] cycloaddition reaction of dicyanamide and azide in the presence of Zn(II) ions at 120, 150, and 180 °C generated [Zn4O(Hbta)3(H2O)6] 1, [Zn7(OH)2(Hbta)6(H2O)6] 2, and [Zn5(OH)4(bta)2]·2H2O 3 (H3bta = N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine), respectively. 1crystallizes in hexagonal space group P6̅2c and shows a layered structure with 3-connected 63-hcb topology in which Zn3O clusters and unsaturated three-coordinate Zn(II) ions function as 3-connected nodes; 2crystallizes in trigonal space group P3̅c1 and also shows a layered structure with (3,6)-connected (43)2(46)-kgd topology in which Zn3O clusters and six-coordinated Zn(II) sites function as 3-connected nodes as 6-connected nodes, respectively; 3 is a 3D organic−inorganic hybrid open framework constructed by Zn5(OH)4 chains. The triply deprotonated bta3− anion is first observed in 3, and rare three-coordinate Zn(II) ions are revealed in 1. Analysis of relationship between structure and synthesis condition reveals that 1 is a metastable kinetic phase whose structure is closely related to that of 2. Both 1 and 2 are constructed by Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn ions. The coordination mode of doubly deprotonated Hbta in 1 and 2 are also same. This study reveals that a higher reaction temperature is helpful to remove amine-hydrogen of H3bta to form triply deprotonated bta anion. The emergence of triply deprotonated bta species may explain why structure of 3 is significantly different from those of 1 and 2. Compounds 1 −3 show strong blue-green emission, assigned as ligand-centered π→π* excitation.

The triply deprotonated bta3- anion is first observed in 3, and rare three-coordinate Zn(II) ions are revealed in 1. Both 1 and 2 are constructed by Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn ions. The coordination mode of doubly deprotonated Hbta in 1 and 2 are also same. This study reveals that a higher reaction temperature is helpful to remove amine-hydrogen of H3bta to form triply deprotonated bta anion. The emergence of triply deprotonated bta species may explain why structure of 3 is significantly different from those of 1 and 2. Compounds 1 -3 show strong blue-green emission, assigned as ligand-centered π→π* excitation.

elements.content: Temperature-tuned hydrothermal [2 + 3] cycloaddition reaction of dicyanamide and azide generated Zn3O cluster-based 3-connected 63-hcb and (3,6)-connected (63)(69.8)-hms layers as well as Zn5(OH)4 chain-based 3D organic−inorganic hybrid open framework. The relationship between structure and reaction temperature has been revealed, and rare three-coordinate Zn(II) centers and unprecedented triply deprotonated N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine have been observed.

The relationship between structure and reaction temperature has been revealed, and rare three-coordinate Zn(II) centers and unprecedented triply deprotonated N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine have been observed.

elements.content: Novel coordination architectures with in situ generated ligands are of great interest in coordination chemistry and organic chemistry for the discovery of new organic reactions and understanding their mechanisms. The tetrazolyl functional group has found a wide range of applications in coordination chemistry as ligands, in pharmaceuticals as a metabolically stable surrogate for a carboxylic acid group, in photography and information recording systems, and in materials science as high-density energy materials. Oragnoazido and azides undergo metal-assisted [2 + 3] cycloaddition with cyano groups yielding a variety of different tetrazole derivatives, which not only offers a safe, convenient, and environmentally friendly synthetic route to tetrazoles but also provides a good method for tetrazole-based coordination polymers.An interesting precursor for cycloaddition reactions with azide is the nonlinear pseudohalide dicyanamide whose complexes have played an important role in the construction of supramolecular aggregates because of their interesting network topologies and potential application as molecular magnets and explosives. The N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine (H3bta), the [2 + 3] cycloaddition product of dicyanamide and azide, has three hydrogen atoms and nine nitrogen donor atoms, and it can coordinate to a metal ion with four reversible species: neutral (H3bta), singly deprotonated (H2bta−), doubly deprotonated (Hbta2−) and triply deprotonated (bta3−) types (Scheme ). However, triply deprotonated bta3− has not been observed due to the difficulty in removing the amine-H atom. Furthermore, no systematic investigation on the relationship between structure and reaction temperature has been performed in the metal-Hnbta system. In the article, we explore the influence of reaction temperature on structure and deprotonation and coordination modes of H3bta species, and report three complexes, namely [Zn4O(Hbta)3(H2O)6] 1, [Zn7(OH)2(Hbta)6(H2O)6] 2 and [Zn5(OH)4(bta)2]·2H2O 3.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Novel coordination architectures with in situ generated ligands are of great interest in coordination chemistry and organic chemistry for the discovery of new organic reactions and understanding their mechanisms. The tetrazolyl functional group has found a wide range of applications in coordination chemistry as ligands, in pharmaceuticals as a metabolically stable surrogate for a carboxylic acid group, in photography and information recording systems, and in materials science as high-density energy materials. Oragnoazido and azides undergo metal-assisted [2 + 3] cycloaddition with cyano groups yielding a variety of different tetrazole derivatives, which not only offers a safe, convenient, and environmentally friendly synthetic route to tetrazoles but also provides a good method for tetrazole-based coordination polymers.An interesting precursor for cycloaddition reactions with azide is the nonlinear pseudohalide dicyanamide whose complexes have played an important role in the construction of supramolecular aggregates because of their interesting network topologies and potential application as molecular magnets and explosives. The N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine (H3bta), the [2 + 3] cycloaddition product of dicyanamide and azide, has three hydrogen atoms and nine nitrogen donor atoms, and it can coordinate to a metal ion with four reversible species: neutral (H3bta), singly deprotonated (H2bta-), doubly deprotonated (Hbta2-) and triply deprotonated (bta3-) types (Scheme ). However, triply deprotonated bta3- has not been observed due to the difficulty in removing the amine-H atom. Furthermore, no systematic investigation on the relationship between structure and reaction temperature has been performed in the metal-Hnbta system. In the article, we explore the influence of reaction temperature on structure and deprotonation and coordination modes of H3bta species, and report three complexes, namely [Zn4O(Hbta)3(H2O)6] 1, [Zn7(OH)2(Hbta)6(H2O)6] 2 and [Zn5(OH)4(bta)2]⋅2H2O 3.

elements.content: All the starting materials were purchased as commercially reagent grade. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in range 400−4000 cm−1 on a Nicolet 5DX spectrometer. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 luminescence spectrometer. Thermal analysis (TG) was carried out in air using SETARAM LABSYS equipment with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All the starting materials were purchased as commercially reagent grade. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in range 400-4000 cm-1 on a Nicolet 5DX spectrometer. Photoluminescence analyses were performed on an Edinburgh FLS920 luminescence spectrometer. Thermal analysis (TG) was carried out in air using SETARAM LABSYS equipment with a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

After cooling to room temperature and filtering, colorless rhombic crystals of 1 in 25% yield were recovered. Anal. Calcd for C6H15N27O7Zn4: C, 8.59; H, 1.80; N, 45.08. elements.content: X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1-3were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated theoretically and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are shown in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Studies

X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for complexes 1-3were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD diffractometer at 293(2) K using Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The program SAINT was used for integration of the diffraction profiles. All the structures were solved by direct methods using the SHELXS program of the SHELXTL package and refined by full-matrix least-squares methods with SHELXL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. All hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were generated theoretically and refined isotropically with fixed thermal factors. Further details for structural analysis are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are shown in Table .

Symmetry codes for 1: (a) −y + 1, x− y, z; (b) x, y, −z + 3/2; (c) −y + 1, x − y − 1, z; (d) −i + y + 2, −x + 1, z; (e) −x + y + 1, −x + 1, z.

Symmetry codes for 2: (a) −x + y, −x, z; (b) x − y, x, −z + 1; (c) −y, x − y, z; (d) −x, −y, −z + 1; (e) y, −x + y, −z + 1; (f) −y + 1, x − y, z; (g) −x + y + 1, −x + 1, z.

Symmetry codes for 3: (a) −x, y, −z + 1/2; (b) −x − 1/2, y − 1/2, −z + 1/2; (c) x + 1/2, y − 1/2, z; (d) −x − 1/2, −y + 1/2, −z.

Compound 1 crystallizes in hexagonal space group P6̅2c and the asymmetric unit consists of two Zn(II) atoms, one doubly deprotonated Hbta group, one oxo, and one water molecule as shown in Figure . The crystallographic −6 axis passes through Zn(2) and O(1) sites. The Zn(1) shows an octahedral geometry, ligated by one μ3-oxo, three nitrogen atoms from two Hbta groups in the equatorial plane and two water molecules at the axial positions. The Zn(2) shows a trigonal geometry, ligated by three nitrogen atoms from three Hbta groups with the Zn(2)−N(4) distance 1.933(12) Å and N−Zn(2)−N angles of 120.00(3)°. The O(1) coordinates to three equivalent Zn(1) ions generating oxo-centered trimeric Zn3O cluster. Within the trimeric Zn3O cluster, the Zn···Zn distance is 3.604 Å and the Zn−O−Zn angle is 120.0°. Each Zn3O cluster is surrounded by three μ3-Hbta groups to form a trigonal Zn3O(Hbta)3 unit. Each Zn(2) is linked to three Zn3O(Hbta)3 units via Zn(2)−N bonds, and vice versus. Considering building units, the formula of 1 can be rewritten as [Zn{Zn3O(Hbta)3(H2O)6}]. The overall structure of 1 is a decorated 3-connected 63-hcb net in which the Zn3O clusters and the Zn(2) centers function as 3-connected nodes (Scheme a). The layers in 1 are packed in AB fashion via hydrogen bond interactions between alternated layers to result in 3-D supramolecular array (Figure c). Namely, layer A is H-bond to layer A and layer B is H-bond to layer B. The H-bond between the alternated layers is only between the Zn3O clusters, which results in a couple of identical 3,5-connected nets. Considering hydrogen bonds between alternate layers, the structure of 1 can be described as a 2-fold interpenetrated 3,5-conn (63)(69.8)-hms net. One of the most remarkable features of 1 is existence of three-coordinate Zn(II) ions. The three-coordinate Zn(II) complexes are extremely rare, most of which are organozinc compounds stabilized by sterically demanding ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Structures

Compound 1 crystallizes in hexagonal space group P6̅2c and the asymmetric unit consists of two Zn(II) atoms, one doubly deprotonated Hbta group, one oxo, and one water molecule as shown in Figure . The crystallographic -6 axis passes through Zn(2) and O(1) sites. The Zn(1) shows an octahedral geometry, ligated by one μ3-oxo, three nitrogen atoms from two Hbta groups in the equatorial plane and two water molecules at the axial positions. The Zn(2) shows a trigonal geometry, ligated by three nitrogen atoms from three Hbta groups with the Zn(2)-N(4) distance 1.933(12) Å and N-Zn(2)-N angles of 120.00(3)°. The O(1) coordinates to three equivalent Zn(1) ions generating oxo-centered trimeric Zn3O cluster. Within the trimeric Zn3O cluster, the Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn distance is 3.604 Å and the Zn-O-Zn angle is 120.0°. Each Zn3O cluster is surrounded by three μ3-Hbta groups to form a trigonal Zn3O(Hbta)3 unit. Each Zn(2) is linked to three Zn3O(Hbta)3 units via Zn(2)-N bonds, and vice versus. Considering building units, the formula of 1 can be rewritten as [Zn{Zn3O(Hbta)3(H2O)6}]. The overall structure of 1 is a decorated 3-connected 63-hcb net in which the Zn3O clusters and the Zn(2) centers function as 3-connected nodes (Scheme a). The layers in 1 are packed in AB fashion via hydrogen bond interactions between alternated layers to result in 3-D supramolecular array (Figure c). Namely, layer A is H-bond to layer A and layer B is H-bond to layer B. The H-bond between the alternated layers is only between the Zn3O clusters, which results in a couple of identical 3,5-connected nets. Considering hydrogen bonds between alternate layers, the structure of 1 can be described as a 2-fold interpenetrated 3,5-conn (63)(69.8)-hms net. One of the most remarkable features of 1 is existence of three-coordinate Zn(II) ions. The three-coordinate Zn(II) complexes are extremely rare, most of which are organozinc compounds stabilized by sterically demanding ligands.

Compound 2 crystallizes in hexagonal space group P3̅c1 and the asymmetric unit consists of two Zn(II) atoms, one doubly deprotonated Hbta group, one hydroxide, and one water molecule as shown in Figure . The crystallographic −3 axis passes through Zn(1) and O(1) sites. The Zn(1) shows an octahedral geometry, ligated by six N(4) atoms from six Hbta groups with the Zn(1)−N(4) distance 2.214(5) Å. The cis-N−Zn(1)−N angles are 88.91(19) and 91.09(19)° and all the three trans-N−Cd(1)−N angles are 180°. The Zn(2) shows a square pyramidal geometry, ligated by one hydroxide, three nitrogen atoms from two Hbta groups in the equatorial plane and one water molecule at the axial position. The μ3-O(1) coordinates to three equivalent Zn(2) ions generating hydroxide-centered trimeric Zn3O cluster. Within the trimeric Zn3O cluster, the Zn···Zn distance is 3.540 Å and the Zn(2)−O(1)−Zn(2) angle is 118.7(2)°. Similar to 1, each Zn3O cluster is surrounded by three μ3-Hbta groups. Each Zn(1) is linked to six Zn3O clusters via Hbta groups while each Zn3O cluster is connected to three Zn(1) atoms. The overall structure of 2 is a doubly decked layer with (3,6)-connected (43)2(46)-kgd net in which the Zn3O clusters and the Zn(1) centers function as 3-connected nodes as 6-connected nodes, respectively (Scheme b). Considering building units, the formula of 2 can be rewritten as [Zn{Zn3(OH)(Hbta)3(H2O)3}2]. The doubly decked layers are packed in AB fashion via hydrogen bond interactions to result in 3D supramolecular array. It should be noted that the structure of 2 is somewhat similar to that of F-centered [Mn{Mn3F(Hbta)3(H2O)6}2].

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and the asymmetric unit consists of three Zn(II) ions, one triply deprotonated bta group, two hydroxides and one water molecule as shown in Figure . The Zn(1) ion localizes at a special position with site occupancy of 0.5, and shows an octahedral ZnO2N4 geometry, coordinated by two hydroxides and four tetrazolyl-N atoms from four bta groups. The Zn(1)−O bond lengths are 2.067(4) Å and the Zn(1)−Ntetrazolyl bond lengths are 2.157(5) and 2.191(5) Å. The cis- and trans-L−Zn−L angles are in the range of 85.5(2)−96.7(3)° and 175.90(18)−179.7(2)°, respectively. The Zn(2) ion shows a distorted square pyramidal ZnO2N3 geometry, coordinated by two hydroxides and two tetrazolyl-N atoms in the equatorial plane and the amine-N at axial position. In the equatorial plane, Zn(2)−O bond lengths are 1.990(4) and 2.107(4) Å; the Zn(2)−Ntetrazolyl bond lengths are 2.045(5) and 2.167(5) Å, whereas the axial Zn(2)−N(9)amine distance is 2.087(5) Å. The N(9)−Zn(2)−L angles are in the range of 94.75(18)-109.00(19)°. The Zn(3) ion shows a distorted tetrahedral ZnO2N2 geometry, coordinated by two hydroxides and two tetrazolyl-N atoms from two bta groups. The Zn(3)−O bond lengths are 1.912(4) and 2.053(4) Å, whereas Zn(3)−Ntetrazolyl bond lengths are 2.018(5) and 2.024(5) Å. The L−Zn−L (L = N, O) angles are in the range of 108.4(2)−120.7(2)°. It should be noted that the triply deprotonated bta group, first observed in 3, is coordinated to six Zn(II) ions in an unprecedented μ6-mode by using seven donor N atoms. There are μ3 and μ2 two types of hydroxides, which are bridged to Zn(II) to form chainlike Zn5(OH)4 motif (Figure b). Alternately, the chain-like Zn5(OH)4 motif is constructed by fusion of Zn4(OH)4 rings and Zn atoms. Actually, the corner-sharing of ZnO2N4 octahedra, ZnO2N3 square pyramids and ZnO2N2 tetrahedra results in an interesting Zn5(OH)4N x polyhedral chain (Figure c). The overall structure of 3 is a 3D organic−inorganic hybrid framework with 1D small channels running along the [101] direction that are occupied by the water molecules. Removing the water, a 22% of voids is computed with PLATON. In order to study the microporosity chemistry of 3, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in air and under 1 atm. pressure at the heating rate of 10 °C min−1 was performed on a polycrystalline sample of 3. TGA trace of 3 (see the ) in air shows a continued mass loss of 4.0% (calcd 4.9%) in the temperature range of 150−340 °C, in agreement with the removal of lattice water molecules. The second mass loss of 39.2% (39.5%) occurred in the temperature range of 400−620 °C, corresponding to the removal of organic bta groups and decomposition of hydroxide as H2O. The final residue of 55.8% (calcd 55.5%) is consistent with the percentage of ZnO in 3. On the basis of the TGA curve, powdered sample of 3 were calcinated in air at 300 °C for 8 h, during which the chlatrate water molecules are removed. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized and calcinated samples are similar, indicating that the porous network of 3 is retained after removal of chlatrate water molecules (see the ).

elements.content: Hydro(solvo)thermal reactions, well-established for the synthesis of zeolites and typically carried out in sealed Teflon bombs and in the temperature range 120−200 °C under autogenous pressure, exploit the self-assembly of the product from soluble precursors. The reduced viscosity of solvents under these conditions enhances the diffusion processes so that crystal growth from solution is favored. Under such nonequilibrium crystallization conditions, metastable kinetic phases, rather than the thermodynamic phase, are most likely to be isolated. After several pathways, the most stable phase also can be isolated. Recent research has revealed that the hydro(solvo)thermal reaction is also a promising technique in preparing complexes with novel structures and special properties, especially in growing crystals of complexes involving in situ ligand synthesis. There are a variety of hydrothermal parameters such as time, temperature, pH value, and molar ratio of reactants, and small changes in one or more of the parameters can have a profound influence on the final reaction outcome.
elements.clean_text:
Relationship between Reaction Temperature and Structure

Hydro(solvo)thermal reactions, well-established for the synthesis of zeolites and typically carried out in sealed Teflon bombs and in the temperature range 120-200 °C under autogenous pressure, exploit the self-assembly of the product from soluble precursors. The reduced viscosity of solvents under these conditions enhances the diffusion processes so that crystal growth from solution is favored. Under such nonequilibrium crystallization conditions, metastable kinetic phases, rather than the thermodynamic phase, are most likely to be isolated. After several pathways, the most stable phase also can be isolated. Recent research has revealed that the hydro(solvo)thermal reaction is also a promising technique in preparing complexes with novel structures and special properties, especially in growing crystals of complexes involving in situ ligand synthesis. There are a variety of hydrothermal parameters such as time, temperature, pH value, and molar ratio of reactants, and small changes in one or more of the parameters can have a profound influence on the final reaction outcome.

elements.content: The synthetic conditions for the three zinc complexes are schematically shown in Scheme . The starting materials and molar ratio in the synthesis of 1−3 are same, and the only difference is reaction temperature. It is interesting to investigate the relationship between reaction temperature and structure of species in 1−3. Both 1 and 2 consist of Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn centers. The coordination mode of doubly deprotonated Hbta in 1 and 2 is also same. In 1, the ratio of Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn ions is 1:1, and the discrete Zn ions are three-coordinate. In contrast, in 2, the ratio of Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn ions is 2:1, and the discrete Zn ions are six-coordinate. This may explain why 1 is a 3-connected 63-hcb layer while 2 is a (3,6)-connected (43)2(46)-kgd layer. The existence of unsaturated three-coordinated Zn(II) ions and synthesis at a lower temperature (120 °C) clearly indicate that 1 is a metastable kinetic phase. When the reaction temperature is lifted to 150 °C, six-coordinate in place of three-coordinated Zn(II) ions are exhibited in 2. However, when the reaction temperature is further increased to 180 °C, a significantly different structure of 3 is obtained. Compound 3 consists of inorganic Zn5(OH)4 chains and contains unprecedented triply deprotonated bta groups. For H3bta, the two tetrazole-H atoms can be easily removed to result in doubly deprotonated Hbta2− anions but the removal of the third hydrogen atom (amine hydrogen) to form bta species is difficult. The unprecedented observation of triply deprotonated bta species in 3 may indicate that a higher reaction temperature is helpful to remove amine-hydrogen of H3bta. The emergence of triply deprotonated bta groups may explain why structure of 3 is significantly different from those of 1 and 2.

elements.content: Compounds 1, 2, and 3 in the solid-state and at ambient temperature show strong and similar fluorescent emissions with maximal emission peaks at 471, 473, and 471 nm, respectively (Figure ). The luminescence in Zn(II) heterocylic complexes has been reviewed by Chen, and their studies reveal that the heteroatom can effectively decrease π and π* orbital energies. Thus HOMO and LUMO of complexes may lack the contribution from metal atoms, and LMCT emission can be excluded and the nature of organic ligand will play a critical role in the photoluminescence mechanism of Zn(II) complexes. The similarity of emissions for 1−3 is in agreement with the explanation, which indicates that ligand-centered π → π* excitation is responsible for these emissions.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescence

Compounds 1, 2, and 3 in the solid-state and at ambient temperature show strong and similar fluorescent emissions with maximal emission peaks at 471, 473, and 471 nm, respectively (Figure ). The luminescence in Zn(II) heterocylic complexes has been reviewed by Chen, and their studies reveal that the heteroatom can effectively decrease π and π* orbital energies. Thus HOMO and LUMO of complexes may lack the contribution from metal atoms, and LMCT emission can be excluded and the nature of organic ligand will play a critical role in the photoluminescence mechanism of Zn(II) complexes. The similarity of emissions for 1-3 is in agreement with the explanation, which indicates that ligand-centered π → π* excitation is responsible for these emissions.

elements.content: The in situ cycloaddition reactions of dicyanamide and azide generated three zinc N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine complexes. Structures of 1 and 2 are related layers constructed by Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn ions. The coordination mode of doubly deprotonated Hbta in 1 and 2 is also same. Compound 1 crystallizes in hexagonal space group P6̅2c and shows a layered structure with 3-connected 63-hcb topology; 2 crystallizes in trigonal space group P3̅c1 and shows a layered structure with (3,6)-connected (43)2(46)-kgd topology. Rare unsaturated three-coordinate Zn(II) centers are exhibited in the metastable kinetic phase of 1. Significantly different, 3 is a 3D organic−inorganic hybrid open framework constructed by Zn5(OH)4 chains. The triply deprotonated bta anion is first observed in 3. Compounds 1−3 show strong blue-green emission, assigned as ligand-centered π→π* excitation.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The in situ cycloaddition reactions of dicyanamide and azide generated three zinc N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine complexes. Structures of 1 and 2 are related layers constructed by Zn3O(Hbta)3 units and discrete Zn ions. The coordination mode of doubly deprotonated Hbta in 1 and 2 is also same. Compound 1 crystallizes in hexagonal space group P6̅2c and shows a layered structure with 3-connected 63-hcb topology; 2 crystallizes in trigonal space group P3̅c1 and shows a layered structure with (3,6)-connected (43)2(46)-kgd topology. Rare unsaturated three-coordinate Zn(II) centers are exhibited in the metastable kinetic phase of 1. Significantly different, 3 is a 3D organic-inorganic hybrid open framework constructed by Zn5(OH)4 chains. The triply deprotonated bta anion is first observed in 3. Compounds 1-3 show strong blue-green emission, assigned as ligand-centered π→π* excitation.

cln_elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c and the asymmetric unit consists of three Zn(II) ions, one triply deprotonated bta group, two hydroxides and one water molecule as shown in Figure . The Zn(1) ion localizes at a special position with site occupancy of 0.5, and shows an octahedral ZnO2N4 geometry, coordinated by two hydroxides and four tetrazolyl-N atoms from four bta groups. The Zn(1)−O bond lengths are 2.067(4) Å and the Zn(1)−Ntetrazolyl bond lengths are 2.157(5) and 2.191(5) Å. The cis- and trans-L−Zn−L angles are in the range of 85.5(2)−96.7(3)° and 175.90(18)−179.7(2)°, respectively. The Zn(2) ion shows a distorted square pyramidal ZnO2N3 geometry, coordinated by two hydroxides and two tetrazolyl-N atoms in the equatorial plane and the amine-N at axial position. In the equatorial plane, Zn(2)−O bond lengths are 1.990(4) and 2.107(4) Å; the Zn(2)−Ntetrazolyl bond lengths are 2.045(5) and 2.167(5) Å, whereas the axial Zn(2)−N(9)amine distance is 2.087(5) Å. The N(9)−Zn(2)−L angles are in the range of 94.75(18)-109.00(19)°. The Zn(3) ion shows a distorted tetrahedral ZnO2N2 geometry, coordinated by two hydroxides and two tetrazolyl-N atoms from two bta groups. The Zn(3)−O bond lengths are 1.912(4) and 2.053(4) Å, whereas Zn(3)−Ntetrazolyl bond lengths are 2.018(5) and 2.024(5) Å. The L−Zn−L (L = N, O) angles are in the range of 108.4(2)−120.7(2)°. It should be noted that the triply deprotonated bta group, first observed in 3, is coordinated to six Zn(II) ions in an unprecedented μ6-mode by using seven donor N atoms. There are μ3 and μ2 two types of hydroxides, which are bridged to Zn(II) to form chainlike Zn5(OH)4 motif (Figure b). Alternately, the chain-like Zn5(OH)4 motif is constructed by fusion of Zn4(OH)4 rings and Zn atoms. Actually, the corner-sharing of ZnO2N4 octahedra, ZnO2N3 square pyramids and ZnO2N2 tetrahedra results in an interesting Zn5(OH)4N x polyhedral chain (Figure c). The overall structure of 3 is a 3D organic−inorganic hybrid framework with 1D small channels running along the [101] direction that are occupied by the water molecules. Removing the water, a 22% of voids is computed with PLATON. In order to study the microporosity chemistry of 3, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) in air and under 1 atm. pressure at the heating rate of 10 °C min−1 was performed on a polycrystalline sample of 3. TGA trace of 3 (see the ) in air shows a continued mass loss of 4.0% (calcd 4.9%) in the temperature range of 150−340 °C, in agreement with the removal of lattice water molecules. The second mass loss of 39.2% (39.5%) occurred in the temperature range of 400−620 °C, corresponding to the removal of organic bta groups and decomposition of hydroxide as H2O. The final residue of 55.8% (calcd 55.5%) is consistent with the percentage of ZnO in 3. On the basis of the TGA curve, powdered sample of 3 were calcinated in air at 300 °C for 8 h, during which the chlatrate water molecules are removed. The X-ray powder diffraction patterns of the as-synthesized and calcinated samples are similar, indicating that the porous network of 3 is retained after removal of chlatrate water molecules (see the ).

Temperature Tuned Synthesis of Zinc N,N-bis-(1(2)H-tetrazol-5-yl)-amine Complexes: From Zn3O Cluster-Based 3-Connected 63-hcb and (3,6)-Connected (43)2(46)-kgd Layers to Zn5(OH)4 Chain-Based 3D Open Framework
